stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on implementing the new “ice-Raven” enemy for the surreal Ice-Palace course, after finishing a Freezy variant and stability refactors.  He also demonstrated recent technical optimizations and discussed planned gameplay tweaks.

development_findings.summary: RTUI refactor restored N64 compatibility and removed crashes, markedly improving overall stability.
development_findings.quote: I spent some time this week refactoring some of the RTUI code base. I got it working on N64 again, fixed a lot of crashes. The game is a lot more stable now.

development_findings.summary: A new delegate system lets HUD elements render on demand, saving about two microseconds per frame.
development_findings.quote: The new system allows us to just render HUD elements anytime we want… we gain like probably two microseconds globally from that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to move frame-buffers into separate memory segments, estimating a 2-3 % (≈1 FPS) speed boost.
development_findings.quote: One more optimization idea… putting the frame buffers into separate memory segments… probably like another two to three percent which… that's like a full FPS.

development_findings.summary: Freezy enemy is considered complete; attention shifted to Yoshi’s Island Ravens adapted as small ice creatures.
development_findings.quote: I think the Raven behavior will be very simple… walk forward and then walk on the geometry and turn around and stuff.

development_findings.summary: Design pivot: at Biobak’s suggestion, Ravens now pop out of the ground, walk a fixed path, then disappear—simpler code and stronger theme.
Raven implementation required converting angles-to-normals for proper wall walking and spawn/vanish animations, revealing Fast64 export precedence bug.
development_findings.quote: This is a Fast64 bug… I need to do that and then it will work.

development_findings.summary: Boss plans: Raffle the Raven will return as an ice-themed boss with moon/cosmic elements, distinct from the regular Ravens.
development_findings.quote: Raffle the Raven is gonna be a boss in this course… There’s definitely gonna be some moon and cosmic elements to it.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is reconsidering the powerful dive-jump after feedback from Dan Salvato; may limit mid-air angle change to preserve Mario 64’s commitment-based design.
development_findings.quote: He said that the dive jump… is kind of against the design of Mario 64 and I can kind of see it.

development_findings.summary: Overall content status: 13 main levels built; still need boss stages, two side levels, a large overworld section, then bug and beta testing.
development_findings.quote: I'm currently working on the 13th level… still need to do boss levels and two side levels and a huge part of the overworld.

development_findings.summary: Kaze contemplates public Course-1 demo builds with varied physics to crowd-source feel feedback.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking of making a bunch of demos of just Course 1, with slight tweaks to the physics, to find physics that people like the most.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a ‘pure platformer’ philosophy—puzzle mechanics are intentionally minimized.
context_findings.quote: Puzzle stuff kind of seems against the basic design of this game.

context_findings.summary: He values novel ideas over repetition, citing fatigue with hacks that offer ‘just platforming’.
context_findings.quote: To me, games is about experiencing new ideas and concepts and I don't really get that from those hacks.

context_findings.summary: Physical exhaustion noted (heavy squats, feeling tired) yet continues coding; shows commitment but hints at work-life strain.
context_findings.quote: Sorry, I just got done doing a heavy set of squats. I'm a little bit out of breath… I'm so tired, so EP.

context_findings.summary: Candid on timeline: expects ‘maybe 2-3 years’ more work.
context_findings.quote: Maybe two to three years more or so. That sounds about right.

context_findings.summary: Streams act as community engagement and morale boost; large raid acknowledged enthusiastically.

biobak.summary: Suggested redesigning Ravens to pop out of ice, walk, and vanish—both cooler thematically and easier to program.
biobak.quote: You can make them pop out of anywhere and it will look cool… It's cooler and easier to program.

biobak.summary: Proposed color/material tweaks (green beak/feet, branch-like hair) and shadow opacity adjustments, influencing final look.

zeina.summary: Provided Raven model and animation (‘Dilly-dally’ loop); collaborated on size and material tweaks.
zeina.quote: Zeina, you sent me the model, right?

zeina.summary: Handled on-stream ‘cumshake’ redemption, showing informal team/personal interaction.

key_stories.title: Pivoting the Raven Enemy
key_stories.summary: Initially, Ravens were to walk along walls and turn on edge detection.  Biobak suggested an alternative: have ice-Ravens burst from the ground, move briefly, then melt away.  Kaze adopted the idea on-stream.
key_stories.challenge: Original wall-walking Ravens were proving complex and hard to place naturally.
key_stories.process: Discussed behavior live; Biobak proposed pop-out mechanic; Kaze weighed theme, difficulty, and code simplicity.
key_stories.outcome: Design switched to pop-out Ravens; implementation completed during stream.
key_stories.key_quote: That's cooler and easier to program.

key_stories.title: Re-evaluating the Dive Jump
key_stories.summary: After Dan Salvato’s critique, Kaze questioned whether the current dive-jump undermines Mario 64’s commitment-based movement.  He brainstormed limits on angle change to keep advanced tech while protecting core design.
key_stories.challenge: Dive-jump allows drastic mid-air corrections inconsistent with original game philosophy.
key_stories.process: Shared feedback, demoed alternatives, gauged chat opinions.
key_stories.outcome: No final decision yet; leaning toward reduced influence version.
key_stories.key_quote: What I was thinking is… you just get a small angle change.

key_stories.title: Micro-Optimization Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Kaze introduced a delegate-based HUD renderer that eliminated per-level hard-coding, reclaiming vital N64 cycles.
key_stories.challenge: HUD elements previously required manual insertion and consumed extra cycles.
key_stories.process: Refactored RTUI; implemented delegate calls; measured gains.
key_stories.outcome: ≈2 μs saved globally; new flexibility for future UI.
key_stories.key_quote: Before that I had to hard-code it, but now I can just use my delegate system.
